Relativity.Toggles

Copyright 2015 kCura Corporation

Overview

Relativity.Toggles is a lightweight .NET library that implements the Feature Toggle pattern.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_toggle

http://martinfowler.com/bliki/FeatureToggle.html

The features of this library include:

  • Simple programming model

  • Toggles are strongly-typed

  • Caching

  • Default values

  • Swappable backend data stores

The library comes with a backend for storing your toggle data in SQL Server. You can easily write your own backend provider if needed.

Configuring Your Environment

Important Note: Several Relativity applications are already configured for feature toggles and do not require any setup. See "Relativity-Specific Integration" for more details.

In order to start using feature toggles, you first need to initialize the toggle library in your application. Configuring the Feature Toggles library requires a few simple steps:

  1. Configure a Toggle Provider
  2. Create the toggle SQL table (if using the built-in SQLServerProvider)
  3. Inject the Toggle Provider into your application

Step 1) Configure a Toggle Provider

var sqlProvider = new SqlServerToggleProvider(connectionFactory, connectionFactoryAsync);

For the SQL Server Provider, you must provide two functions that provide the necessary database connections. The only difference between the methods is that one supports the async / await pattern and the other creates the connection synchronously. The connection returned by these functions should be open and ready to be used.

Step 2) Create the Toggle SQL table

If you are using the built-in SQLServerProvider, you will need to create a SQL table to store your toggle states. Look at the schema.sql file in this repository for a script you can run against your database to create this table.

Note that this table already exists in the EDDS database since we've already integrated the toggles library with Relativity. So you shouldn't need to do this for anything related to Relativity.

Step 3) Inject the Toggle Provider into your application.

Making the provider available to your application code can be done one of two ways: the Global Provider or via dependency injection.

Option 1: Use the Global Toggle Provider

To use the global toggle provider, you set the static ToggleProvider.Current property as shown in the example below.

var sqlProvider = new SqlServerToggleProvider(connectionFactory, connectionFactoryAsync);

ToggleProvider.Current = sqlProvider;

Option 2: Use Dependency Injection

You can let your dependency injection container provide the IToggleProvider instance to the classes in your application.

var sqlProvider = new SqlServerToggleProvider(connectionFactory, connectionFactoryAsync);

var container = new WindsorContainer(); // Use Castle Windsor as an example

container.Register(
    Component.For<IToggleProvider>()
    .Instance(sqlProvider)
    .LifestyleSingleton());
Creating Feature Toggles

Creating a toggle is as simple as creating a new class:

public class MyFeatureToggle : IToggle {}

Your toggle class must implement IToggle (it is an empty interface with no methods to implement). That's it!

Turning Toggles On and Off (SQLServerProvider)

Go to the [Toggle] table in your database to configure new toggles. The table has two columns:

Name: The fully-qualified name of your toggle class (e.g. Relativity.Web.MyFeatureToggle).

IsEnabled: 1 == on, 0 == off

Checking Feature Toggles

You now use the toggle provider from Step 3 to check your new toggle:

bool isEnabled = await provider.IsEnabledAsync<MyFeatureToggle>();

There is also a synchronous version of the same call:

bool isEnabled = provider.IsEnabled<MyFeatureToggle>();
Default Values

By default, if a toggle can't be found in the data store an exception is thrown of type MissingToggleException. However, in some cases you might want to provide a default value for a toggle. For example, you may not want any trace of a toggle to be visible in your database so end users don't go changing values.

You can accomplish this in two different ways:

Via the Provider

Every toggle provider has a property called DefaultMissingFeatureBehavior. You can set this property to control whether to throw or assign a default value:

provider.DefaultMissingFeatureBehavior = MissingFeatureBehavior.Enabled;

Per Toggle

You can set the default value on a per-toggle basis using the DefaultValueAttribute. Default values set using this attribute override the provider's behavior.

// This toggle class will default to true if the toggle is missing

[DefaultValue(true)]
public sealed class MyToggleWithADefault : IToggle {}
Toggle Aliasing

By default, the toggles library will use the name of a toggle's class to keep track of whether it is enabled or disabled. There may be cases, however, where you want to use a name other than its class. For example, maybe sharing a reference to your toggle between assemblies is not feasible. In that case, you can create your toggle classes separately, and use aliasing to ensure they point to the same underlying data.

You can specify a toggle's name using the ToggleAlias attribute. When using the ToggleAlias attribute, the class name becomes an alias for your specified toggle name and is no longer used internally.

// This toggle class will act just like a Relativity.Web.MyFeatureToggle class

[ToggleAlias("Relativity.Web.MyFeatureToggle")]
public sealed class MyAliasedToggle : IToggle {}
Caching

Going to the data store for every toggle check can get expensive. The Toggles library supports simple, in-memory caching. You control caching at the toggle provider.

provider.CacheEnabled = true;
provider.CacheTimeoutInSeconds = 30;

Every toggle is cached for the same amount of time. The cache is off by default; you must turn it on and set a cache duration. You can choose any cache duration that is reasonable for your application.

Relativity-Specific Integration

Environment Configuration:

The toggle provider is configured at startup in almost all parts of Relativity. This includes:

  • Relativity Web
  • Event Handlers
  • Agents
  • Custom Pages
  • Kepler Services

If you notice an area of the software that is not pre-configured with the toggle provider, please reach out to the Platform team.

You do not have to configure the toggles for every visual studio project - just the top-level application / executable for the AppDomain.

Database:

The Relativity Toggle table is stored in at [EDDS].[eddsdbo].[Toggle]

Default Values:

All Relativity feature toggles should configure default values at the toggle level.

Caching:

Relativity is pre-configured for 30-second caching of all feature toggles.

Best Practices

Toggles vs User Config: Feature toggles are primarily an internal-facing config option, as opposed to EDDS config which is meant for our clients. One of the main use cases for feature toggles is reducing the need for feature branches. Use toggles primarily for this purpose. If a feature truly should be user-facing (as to whether it is on or off), make it an EDDS config setting instead of a feature toggle.

Clean Up Your Toggles: Make sure you regularly clean up your feature toggles. Toggles add temporary tech debt, so don't let them linger after their usefulness. Keep tasks on your backlog to remove the toggles when you are sure that the feature is shipping.

Hidden Toggles: If it is important for a feature to be hidden from clients in production, you can use the DefaultValue attribute to set the toggle to true or false. You then don't have to include a row in the toggle table in production - but you still have the option of explicitly turning the toggle on or off.

Give Feedback: Using Feature toggles is a new process at kCura. Please submit your feedback to SEAT so we can update our best practices and make useful changes to the library.
